thread.title: ’Devs ground ’n’ pound T-birds: River Valley amasses 450 yards rushing in 43-7 romp over Mohave
thread.title_full: ’Devs ground ’n’ pound T-birds: River Valley amasses 450 yards rushing in 43-7 romp over Mohave

author: DANIEL McKILLOP The Daily News
title: ’Devs ground ’n’ pound T-birds: River Valley amasses 450 yards rushing in 43-7 romp over Mohave
text:
DANIEL McKILLOP/The Daily News SPEED TO BURN 
Dust Devils running back Andres Galvez (1) gallops to what appeared to be a 90-yard TD as T-birds linebacker Takory Brown (31) attempts to chase him down; however, a yellow hanky lies on the ground signifying a holding penalty and it was all for naught. Posted: Sunday, October 11, 2015 12:55 am | Updated: 1:15 am, Sun Oct 11, 2015. ’Devs ground ’n’ pound T-birds: River Valley amasses 450 yards rushing in 43-7 romp over Mohave By DANIEL McKILLOP The Daily News MohaveDailyNews.com | 0 comments 
MOHAVE VALLEY — The Dust Devils amassed 450 yards rushing en route to their 43-7 rout over the T-birds at River Valley High School on Friday night. 
River Valley running back Andres Galvez gained 140 yards rushing on 10 carries with two TD runs and he also recorded a 55-yard catch-and-run TD. 
Galvez also had a 90-yard TD run negated because of a holding penalty. 
The Dust Devils’ defense helped put the game’s first three points on the board during the contest’s very first possession. 
RVHS linebacker Jacob Lee burst through the line of scrimmage and blocked a punt and defensive lineman Steve Holmes recovered the football at the Mohave High School 13-yard line, which helped set up Bryson Fohs’ 41-yard field goal with 7:48 left in the first quarter. 
Lee also blocked a punt and fell on the ball in the end zone during the game’s first possesson during the Dust Devils’ victory against the Bulldogs at Kingman High School on Sept. 25. 
“I feel like it is a good habit to have, putting my team/offense in a position to go get a score,” said Lee about his second blocked punt in three weeks. 
RVHS co-head coach and defensive coodinator Mark Ruckle said Jacob Lee is a “special guy. 
“He has been with me four years, he knows what I want, he studies, he’s prepared, he’s aggressive, his motor doesn’t stop and he’ll be playing at the next level next year. 
“He’s the guy making everything work on the defense and that’s a tribute to him and the guys.” 
Galvez turned a fake punt into a 45-yard TD run, which put RVHS ahead 9-0 after the 2-point conversion failed at 3:58. 
Despite trailing by nine, the T-birds’ defense was playing well until this point, but River Valley’s next touchdown took the air out of Mohave’s balloon. 
Dust Devils quarterback Ryan Economou’s double play-action, misdirection fake and 55-yard catch-and-run TD pass to Galvez made it 16-0 after Fohs’ extra point at 2:24. 
“I faked to right to Anderson, then faked to the left to Galvez,” Economou said. “I rolled out a little bit to the right, I juked out one T-bird and looked back side and saw Galvez beating the (linebacker) and threw it to him.” 
MHS head coach Rudy Olvera added: “It was a heck of a play. He had a linebacker running with him and he put the ball right in his hands.” 
Mohave linebacker/running back Takory Brown said it was disappointing because the T-birds really want to win. 
“We were making tackles, we were sprinting to the ball,” said Brown about Mohave’s early success defensively. 
Ruckle said RVHS co-head coach and offensive coordinator Paul Ducchaineau was looking at what Mohave was doing defensively. 
“Then we were trying some different things we were putting together while the game was being played, a game plan where we could attack,” Ruckle said. “Once we saw where their weakness 
was, that’s just where we just kept coming at them.” 
Galvez’s 67-yard TD run, Fohs’ PAT, made it 23-0 with 8:07 to go in the second period. 
“They broke a couple of tackles,” Olvera said. “We just have to tackle better.” 
Galvez suffered a hamstring injury and was removed from the game in the third period. 
“I hope Galvez is OK,” Olvera said. “He’s a great football player. 
“I hate to see a kid go down.” 
Economou’s 31-yard catch-and-run TD pass to wide receiver David Larrabee, Foh’s PAT, made it 30-0 at 3:53. 
“We did a very good job defensively,” T-birds lineman Dom Larocque said. “But once we give up a couple of scores, (we) put our heads down.” 
The T-birds broke the Dust Devils’ 4 1 / 2 game shutout streak when quarterback Oliver Syme tossed a 10-yard TD pass to tight end Matt McKee, McKee PAT, which made it 30-7 at 30.7 seconds. 
When McKee was asked how he felt about breaking River Valley’s shutout streak, he said, “It felt pretty good. 
“Our passing was pretty good at the end of the first half.” 
Lee, who was at fullback periodically on offense, scored on an 11-yard TD run, Fohs’ PAT, made it 37-7 with 7:21 left in the third period. 
Dust Devils fullback Devin Anderson’s 22-yard TD run made it 43-7 at 2:31. 
“I think we’ve got a great stable of backs, they’re a bunch of kids who’ve got speed and are tough,” Ruckle said. “Galvez would’ve had 300 yards if there weren’t some issues. 
“I think all of those guys came out tonight with the intention of taking it to them and running hard.” 
Anderson gained 112 yards on 11 carries and Fohs gained 127 yards on nine carries. 
Fohs ran for 71 yards one play after Galvez’s 90-yard TD run was called back. 
The victory improved River Valley’s record to 6-1 overall, 4-0 in section. 
“I can’t say enough about what they’re doing,” said Olvera about the Dust Devils. “They play hard; Ruckle always has a good scheme.” 
The Dust Devils’ defense held Mohave running backs Jason Urquiza to 30 yards on 19 carries and Brown to 29 yards on six carries. 
“I think we did well,” RVHS defensive lineman Tyler Garringer said. “We stopped the run; it was hard work and preparaton all week.” 
Olvera said he told his T-birds “let’s get back to work — that’s our mantra” during his postgame speech. 
He added: “Let’s sweep the city of Kingman.” 
The loss dropped the AIA Division IV, Section III T-birds’ record to 2-5 overall, 2-2 in section. 
The T-birds will play the Volunteers at Lee Wiliams High School on Friday, the Bulldogs of Kingman High School at Mohave on Oct. 23, and the Tigers at Kingman Academy on Oct. 30. 
The Dust Devils play the Wranglers at Wickenburg High School on Friday.
